course.subject: MATH
course.name: Applied Linear Algebra and Differential Equations
course.description: This course provides a concise introduction to linear algebra and differential equations, with exposure to the use of numerical computing software like MATLAB. Topics include systems of linear equations, matrix algebra and determinants, language of vector spaces and inner product spaces, eigenvalue and eigenvector, first order ODEs, linear second order ODEs and oscillations, and homogeneous system of first order ODEs with constant coefficients.
course.prerequisites: A passing grade in AL Pure Mathematics / AL Applied Mathematics OR MATH 1014 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH 1024
course.exclusions: MATH 2111, MATH 2121, MATH 2131, MATH 2351, MATH 2352, PHYS 2124

reviews.author: Haumang
reviews.comment_content:
The course is divided into two parts, Matrix Algebra (Midterm) and Ordinary Differential Equation (Final).

A. Matrix Algebra
1. Complex Numbers
2. Matrices
3. System of Linear Equations
4. Vector Spaces
5. Determinants
6. Eigenvalues & Eigenvectors

B. ODE
1. First Order ODE
2. Second order ODE
3. Series solutions of homogeneous linear second order equations
4. Systems of linear differential equations

Actually, the lecture note from prof and the worksheets in the tutorial are enough. A textbook is not a must.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor follows the lecture note to teach. He recorded video for us to watch on Youtube and Coursera. He gave us some extra examples of some difficult concepts and calculations. He is really patients and nice.
The tutorial is just giving our time to finish the questions after demonstrate a few questions. If you have any question, you can go to the front and ask Qing.
reviews.comment_grading:
The exam questions are based on worksheets in tutorials. Solutions of the worksheets will be provided on the tutorial homepage. Just work on it seriously before the exam.

Assessment Mode:
10% for tutorial worksheets
40% Midterm (total 8 Q.)
50% Final

Absolute and relative grading systems are provided. As the exam is easy, you can get A range easily. More than 50% of students got A range. CRAZY!
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is low.
This course only requires to finish the weekly worksheets in tutorials. Just try your best to hand in as many solved practice problems as time permits to receive the full marks.
Besides, it is not a difficult course. Just revise the steps before the exam. Then, it is ok.

reviews.comment_content:

Week 4:
3.1-3.4 Vector and inner-product spaces,  
Week 5:

Week 6:

Week 7:

Week 8

reviews.comment_teaching:
In fact, I only attended the first lecture because I think the professor was teaching too fast during the lecture. He spent most of the time on proving the formulas without giving some time for you to digest the content. So, I skipped the remaining lectures.

Instead of attending the lectures, I learned the course content on Coursera, this platform provided nearly the same learning materials with explicit explanation videos on each topic (much better than lectures!!!!). On top of that, the learning videos and materials on Coursera are also provided by Chasnov. So, you don't have to worry about the discrepancy between the lecture content and the content on Coursera. Some of the content on Coursera is not covered by this course and you can refer to the course outline to study the relevant topics.

The tutorials provided some exercises on different topics, these exercises are highly similar to the mid-term and final exam. Remember to do the exercises before the exams!!!

reviews.author: jason0119
reviews.title: This is a good grade course
reviews.comment_content:
Course Review:
1. Complex Numbers

2. Different Types of Matrices; Matrix Manipulation

3. Systems of Linear Equations, Gaussian Elimination; Inverses of Matrices and LU Decomposition

4. Vector & Dot Product Spaces

5. 4 Types of Vector Spaces; Gram-Schmidt Process; Orthogonal Projections

6. Least Squares Problem; Matrix Determinants

7. Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors

8. Separable and First-Order Linear Odes

9. Applications of Point 8

10. Homogeneous and Inhomogeneous Second-Order Odes

11. Resonance

12. Series Solutions; Phase-Space Diagrams

13. Normal Modes
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jeffery is a nice teacher who will provide a lot of materials for his lectures. He is also a easy going person who is willing to help his students to get good grades and learn the essential skill from the course.
There is office hours for him every week in order to answer the students' question.
For tutorial, ta will give us simple to difficult questions to ensure the students can learn this course from scratch. They are nice to reply all the emails from me.
reviews.comment_grading:
In our semester, the grading is absolute grading, the assessment scheme as below:
Matrix Algebra: 40% (Coursera problems: 10%; Coursera assessments: 10%; Midterm: 20%)
Differential Equations: 60% (Coursera problems: 15%; Coursera assessments: 15%; Final 30%)
Absolute Grading: A: 90-100%; B:80-89%; C: 70-79; D: 65-69; F:0-64. Plus and minus to be decided.
Finally, I got an A grade which is really good for me. The exams are open notes and easy to handle. There is plenty of time for you to finish.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is light. Although there are homework every week but they are all shot questions. Besides, they provide answers before hand to make sure you can understand how to do the questions.
For examination, I took around a week to study for mid-term exam and also final exam respectively.

reviews.author: David24A
reviews.comment_content:
1. Complex Numbers
2. Different Types of Matrices; Matrix Manipulation
3. Systems of Linear Equations, Gaussian Elimination; Inverses of Matrices and LU Decomposition
4. Vector & Dot Product Spaces
5. 4 Types of Vector Spaces; Gram-Schmidt Process; Orthogonal Projections
6. Least Squares Problem; Matrix Determinants
7. Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
8. Separable and First-Order Linear Odes
9. Applications of Point 8
10. Homogeneous and Inhomogeneous Second-Order Odes
11. Resonance
12. Series Solutions; Phase-Space Diagrams
13. Normal Modes
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jeffery is not a bad lecturer. He makes his own notes and uses them for lecture. Only thing about that though is that he sticks to the notes a little too much, so you can just read the notes and not focus. Keep in mind that you will miss out on the proper explanations if you don't listen to him. He also has a Coursera course and YouTube videos in case you missed the lectures. The IRL lectures though are a little boring. Sometimes, he cracks a few jokes but they're usually hit and miss.

He tells you what each of the problems are before the exam so you have a better idea of what you should revise. There are also worksheets in the tutorials that gives you more opportunity to revise. The questions themselves are pretty well made and can warm you up to the exams. The one about Applications of First Order Linear Odes is hell though. Don't try to do that one.

In each tutorial, you listen to the tutor explain in detail what you've learned and do a few selected questions on the worksheet. The guy does speak a little too quietly, so keep your ears peeled.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading methods: absolute grading or relative grading. Whichever method used depends on the performance of the students. The exact details of each method is already in another review so I won't bother typing it all out.

Worksheets: 10%
Midterm: 40%
Final: 50%

My score:
Worksheets: 24/24
Midterm: 71/80
Final: 62/80

Overall: 84.25/100
Mean: 71.395
SD: 18.232

Grade: B+

The Midterm only consists of topics about Matrices and Complex Numbers and the Final only consists of topics about Differential Equations, except maybe Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors.

If you decide to take this course, I advise focusing on Vector Spaces, Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors, Resonance, Phase-Space Diagrams and Normal Modes. These topics are quite hard, especially if you don't have adequate knowledge in physics beforehand.

The grading is really lenient and the exams are not difficult, so expect very good results if you work hard.
reviews.comment_workload: There is barely any workload other than the worksheets. If you work hard, this course should be a breeze.

不過Jeffrey會喺考試前透露考試題目嘅相應topic，學生只要完成相應嘅worksheet就能夠取得可觀嘅分數。(worksheet題型同考試幾乎一模一樣)

reviews.author: つち
reviews.title: Easiest course to get an A+
reviews.comment_content:
This course is divided into 2 parts.

The first part is about linear algebra, which involves complex number, matrices. For someone who have not studied matrix yet (just like me), I think it is still easy to follow. The main content of this part is related to matrices.

The second part is about solving ordinary differential equations in 1st and 2nd order.
We learn how to use ansartz to solve the equations and also how to sketch phase diagrams.
reviews.comment_teaching:
In lectures, professor teaches us based on his lecture notes. He provides a few hardcopies for us to buy but I think it is not really necessary since we can get the softcopy from his course website for free. For the second part of the course, we have another updated notes for differential equations with exercises and answers.

In tutorials, we have to complete a worksheet for exercises in each tutorial. Actually, you can get the mark if you really attend it and put some effort to do the exercises. It is not necessary to complete all the questions and get all of them correct.

Although some questions on the worksheet maybe more difficult than the midterm and final exam, I still suggest you to put some effort on the tutorial questions since they can really help you to understand more on how to apply the methods you have learnt.
reviews.comment_grading:
Extremely good grade. About 25% students got an A+, which requires overall 97% !
I think the main reason is that the midterm and final exams are so similar to the practise paper provided by the professor.

Grading:
10% tutorial
40% midterm
50% final
There are 2 schemes for letter grades.
One is the absolute grading and one is the relative grading.
Since most of the students get good results, absolute grading is used most.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not high. You can choose to attend the lectures, read the notes or watch the online video on youtube or coursera.

Just finish the tutorial worksheets every week and do the practise paper to check your understanding before the exams, then you should be able to get good results.

reviews.author: I Want 1st Hon!
reviews.title: Basic Physics Background is Needed; Good Professor, Good TA!
reviews.comment_content:
This course is divided into 2 individual parts,
1st: Linear Algebra (before midterm, 8 questions for Midterm, equal weighting for each question)
2nd: Differential Equations (DE) (after midterm, 8 questions for Final ONLY, equal weighting for each question).

For the whole course, it is mostly step-memorising. You have a standard procedure for either Linear Algebra or DE Calculation! However, there are some physics for DE parts, e.g. RLC Circuit (**Non-dimensionalize), Pendulum, Mass spring system/Normal mode, escape velocity (This year exam questions from tutorial 9: applications of ODEs), terminal velocity; and some other applications: compound interest, chemical reactions, logistic equation, and so on.

**it is the most difficult topics that I personal think!

I stay at home to watch the lecture video except the first lecture. I do agree you attend the first lecture to know more about the professor. Then, just sit at home and watch the lecture video in 1.5-2 times speed (usually post after 1 day afternoon).

For both exams, no calculator & closed books; There are 13 tutorial worksheets, and each of them counts (0-2 marks): most people got full marks! (Some weeks will be extremely hard: application of ODEs (Tutorial 9))

My personal suggestion: as there is no calculator allowed in exam, some of the worksheets which may require the use of calculator SHOULD NOT be in exam. Be smart and choose the possible questions to practice!!

P.S. This course is mostly CIVL, CBE, MECH students!
reviews.comment_teaching:
The reasons I mentioned that you watch the lecture videos:
1. Professor seldom answers students’ questions in lecture (Not many students have questions)
2. Professor speaks in an extremely slow pace, that 2x speed may be your best choice.
3. The content the professor teaches refers mostly to his book, which can be downloaded from his MATH2350 website. You can sit at home and read it/or print it (probably $33, depending on the edition, since he updates his notes quick often (NOT within the semester, but weeks before the semester))/or buy it ($40) later!

The best parts for students: professor gives most of the hints (topics and reminders) for both midterm and final.

Besides, one of the two TAs, Justin (Sun Jia Ze), he can speak cantonese, and he teaches very well. He allows us to send a softcopy through email to him OR put the hardcopy outside the TA office (Lift 21 Rm3213, I am not sure whether it will change in later years). He always responds to my email (he is responsible and helps us to get good grade, by answering questions in a well manner!)

The TA makes his own notes which I think it is extremely useful, and you will know why. Please trust me! Moreover, he is good at communicating as his Cantonese, Mandarin/Putonghua, English are all good!!!

THE BEST TAs I have seen in this semester!!!!!
reviews.comment_grading:
My Score:
65/80 in midterm (40%) (Mean~51, SD~17)
73/80 in final (50%) (Mean~46, SD~16)
26/26 for 13 Tutorial worksheets (10%) (2 marks full marks each!)
Grade: A+, MY 1st A+ in HKUST :)

Fair grading. Two schemes for your grade: absolute grading and normal distribution. One of the schemes counts the best grade and that will be your final grade.

Both midterm and final was really fair in difficulty, in addition of his tips for the topics that he examined. JUST BE CAREFUL!!!!! This year's exam is more difficult than last year, according to the professor. Hence, professor set the fail marginal line as total 30 mark instead of 50, due to the poor performance this year.
reviews.comment_workload:
For 10% mark (Tutorial), depending on your TAs, and whether they allow you to skip the tutorial, and hand in the softcopy of the worksheets before the tutorial.
The risk depends on everyone, whether you think the tutorial is useful. I suggest you attend at least two tutorials for the whole semester.

For 40% mark (Midterm) & 50% mark (Final), they really depend on you, being careful & smart? Most of the questions should be practice-based, i.e. you should have already done most of the similar questions. Professor only changes the form a little, and something you cannot find online, e.g. normal mode (2 springs, 3 masses)

If you do all the exercise once/twice in detail and understand most of the concepts, and be careful in exam, you can probably get A range! Just honest saying!

reviews.author: JAM
reviews.comment_content: The course is divided into two parts, the first on is about matrix (until midterm) and the second is about differential equations (after midterm). Matrix is relatively easier compared to the differential equations. For the ODE, you need to memorise steps of each case. i.e. which step should you use for homogenous and inhomogeneous, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
In my opinion, I like his teaching style. Although some may find his pace quite fast, but for me the pace was just right. He seemed to be more passionate about ODEs than matrix.

The midterm questions were really similar to the practice exercise he gave. But there were no exercises for finals, although he gave A LOT of hints, tips and tricks at the last lecture meeting. So it is important to attend the last if you don't normally go to his lectures. Lecture videos were also available.
reviews.comment_grading: I would say the grading was not as lenient as I thought. You will be given your best score calculated from absolute scheme and normal distribution. Midterm was super easy so the mean was really high.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is pretty light, although you need to attend tutorials since it will be graded. No webworks. Only finals and midterms.

reviews.author: smiling
reviews.comment_content:
Ch 0 A short mathematical review

Part I Linear algebra
Ch 1 The language of linear algebra
Ch 2 Matrices
Ch 3 Systems of linear equations
Ch 4 Determinants
Ch 5 Eigenvalues and eigenvectors

Part II Differential equations
Ch 6  Introduction to odes (ordinary differential equations)
Ch 7 First-order odes
Ch 8 Second-order odes, constant coefficients
Ch 9 Series solutions
Ch 10 Systems of linear differential equations
Ch 11 Nonlinear differential equations

Complex number is involved in solving odes with complex distinct roots.

If you are local student studying M2 before, then Ch 2-4 are piece of cake to you, but there are still some new topics and concepts in the linear algebra part such as vector space, subspace, inner product, outer product, trace of square matrix, rotation matrix, orthogonal matrix, eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. CHASNOV teaches by following the lecture notes. I personally think that his teaching pace is quite fast and I cannot catch up in his lectures (especially in the differential equations part). If you cannot catch up, it is better to study the lecture notes after the lecture though it is quite clumsy and involves many words.

Instead of using Canvas, professor designs a web page for this course. All useful materials are in there. Lecture videos are provided.
reviews.comment_grading:
13 Worksheets : 10%
Midterm : 40%
Final : 50%

Only Linear algebra is examined in midterm and only Differential equations is examined in final.

Grade is based on either absolute or relative grading scale. You will receive a better grade among
the two grading scales.

Absolute grading scheme :
97-100  A+
93-96  A
90-92  A-
87-89  B+
83-86  B
80-82  B-
77-79  C+
73-76  C
70-72  C-
65-69  D
<65  F
*According to the last few sentences below the grading scale, passing this course requires students to get total scores higher than 50. Thus, range of D grade should be (50,69] and range of F grade should be <=50.

Relative grading scale :
(Your scores) > mean+1SD                A range
mean < (Your scores) < mean+1SD   B range
mean-1SD < (Your scores) < mean    C range
mean-2SD < (Your scores) < mean-1SD   D
(Your scores) < mean-2SD                         F

Midterm exam is very easy to most students while final exam is more difficult than midterm.
BE CAUTIOUS in midterm as many students got FULL MARKS in midterm!!! If you make a minor mistake in one question, you will probably be below mean.

Statistic :
worksheets  mean : 25.6/26
midterm  mean : 43.78/50  SD : 6.94
final  mean : 57.4/80  SD : unknown

Overall mean : 80.74%
Normal/bad grade same as most UST courses
reviews.comment_workload:
Main workload is the 13 worksheets. One worksheet per week which is quite annoying. The TA in my tutorial session gave us the worksheet by email one day before the tutorial and we need to submit it in the tutorial. Different TAs have different style in distributing the worksheets, I heard that TA in other session distributed worksheets in the tutorial which means students must finish it within the tutorial. Worksheets actually are the assignments and you need to attend the tutorial to submit them.

Worksheet grading scheme :
0 marks  unexcused absent students
1 mark    students who only make a minimal effort
2 marks  students who make a reasonable effort

*most students got full marks in worksheets

reviews.author: mpkin
reviews.title: A new mathematic course which improvement is needed
reviews.comment_content:
The course mainly covers two parts, including linear algebra and ordinary differential equation (ODE).  Calculation by computer programme (GNU Octave) is also included.

According to the plan of the instructor, linear algebra is taught in the first half of the semester, while the second half of the semester is used to introduce the ODE calculation.

In my opnion, this syllabus of the course is too wide, and it seems to squeeze the material of two courses into one course.  
As a result, the instructor used about 3/4 of the semester to teach linear algebra, while only about 3 to 4 weeks to teach ODE.  I found it hard to follow such a lot of material in a short time.

On the other hand, the computer programme part (GNU octave) of the course is not adquate, because the instructor just do few dememonstrations in lessons, without fully explain the function of the commands.  As a result, this part is also hard to follow, and there are difficulties for us to use the techniques of the programme taught in the course in the future.
reviews.comment_teaching:
There are lecture notes for each chapter of the course, which is highly informative (150 slides in average).  In other words, there are lots of proves which are not useful are put in the notes.

Due to the lack of time, the instructor ususally skip notes, so it is hard for me to catch up, and know which part is important in the lecture notes of 150 slides.

As a result, I need to revise at home by myself in order to tackle the examination.
Note that the instructor is kind and willing to answer our question.

The instructor has uploaded a set of notes about matlab (computer programme), however, he didn't use the notes much, and I need to spend time to read it by myself.

About the tutorial, Ms. Zhang, luchan has done a great job, because she taught the material exceptionally clear, and whe is willing to answer question patiently that we raised in class.  She will also reply email quickly if we ask question by sending email.
reviews.comment_grading:
Here below are the weightings of the course:
Homework: 12%
Quiz: 3%
Mid-term: 35%
Final: 50%

Here are some statistics of the course:
Mid-term -   Mean: 80 / SD: 12
Final -  Mean: 65.1 / SD: 15.6

The content of mid-term is quite easy compare to things in the lecture notes, while final is a bit harder than that.
The grading is normal (for a mathematics course) with about mean get B-.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not high, while lot of time is needed for self revision after lecture.

There are 11 homeworks and 3 quizzes about computer programme.  It takes some times to finish the homework if you don't know much about the content taught in the lecture.

In conclusion, take account of the fact that this course is a new course, there may be lack of experience in organizing the course material, hope that the planning course will be better next semester.

reviews.author: J.Henderson
reviews.title: Worst lecturer I have seen
reviews.comment_content: This course consists of two parts: linear algebra and ode. Towards the end of the course, you will learn solving systems of ode, which is a mix of two parts. You only need to memorize the computations and neglect the proof for the midterm and final exam. A few multiple choice questions in both midterm and final are about octave commands, so you should at least have a look at them.
reviews.comment_teaching: Completely rubbish. Don't attend the lectures because it will be a mere waste of time. The lecture notes are also useless. For the linear algebra part, revise Dr Wong's MATH2011 notes instead. For the ODE part, good luck.
reviews.comment_grading: The midterm is quite easy but I think the final is much more difficult. I don't understand why octave commands are tested in the exam when there already have quizzes on octave which cost about 3% of the total grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Although there are only quizzes and webwork (excluding midterm and final), you need constant revision because the teaching is so fxcking bad. Good luck to all of you who needs to take MATH2350 in the future.

reviews.author: Waigor
reviews.title: So Fked Up
reviews.comment_content: Lecture notes, ppt, tutorial materials are basically useless. Some difficult theorems are presented in only one page, proofs are often omitted.
reviews.comment_teaching: Sure that Lee wing lung doesnt know how to teach, he's been into the wrong profession. Seriously, he even doesnt understand the content. It's not your loss not to attend his class.
reviews.comment_grading: Mean score in midterm is pretty high as the paper is easy. But, the case is totally different in the final exam. If you didnt take M2 in secondary school, good luck.

reviews.author: B_csh
reviews.comment_content:
Linear algebra
Week 1:
0.14 Course introduction; complex numbers
Week 2:
1.1-1.8 Matrices, transposes, inverses, rotations, permutations, projections
Week 3:
2.1-2.5 Gaussian elimination, reduced row echelon form, inverses, LU decomposition
Week 4:
3.1-3.4 Vector and inner-product spaces,  
Week 5:
3.5-3.7 Four fundamental vector spaces of a matrix, Gram-Schmidt, orthogonal projections  
Week 6:
3.9-3.10, 4.1-4.3 Least squares, determinants  
Week 7:
5.1-5.3 Eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization

Differential equation
Week 8  
6.1, 7.1, 7.2, 7.3 Introduction to odes, Euler method, separable equations, linear equations
Week 9
7.4, 8.1- 8.3 Applications, Euler method 2D, superposition, Wronskian
Week 10
8.4-8.6 Homogeneous odes, difference equations, inhomogeneous odes
Week 11
8.8-8.9 Inhomogeneous odes, resonance, applications, damped resonance
Week 12
9, 10.1-10.4 Series solutions, systems of first-order linear odes
Week 13
10.5 Normal modes, Final exam review

Some of them learnt in M2 and some of them are totally new such as vector space, Eigenvalues and eigenvectors etc.

If you do not understand the topic at all, somehow you can recite the process of calculation and get full mark in midterm and final. Some require understanding such as those application topic and normal modes.

Most importantly, finish all worksheets!!!! The questions in midterm and final are very similar to the question in the worksheets.

Also, before the midterm and final, there was a review section to talk about some important points. Before the final, he will tell you the topics for each question. You can expect what you will see in the exam.

reviews.author: Mango Pudding
reviews.title: Be sure to score close to full marks in both exams for A-range grades
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture notes: https://www.math.hkust.edu.hk/~machas/applied-linear-algebra-and-differential-equations.pdf
(Not everything in the notes will be taught and tested)

=== Part 1: Linear Algebra ===
► Complex numbers
► Matrix
   • DSE M2 Matrix stuff
   • Rotational, orthogonal matrices
   • Permutation matrix
► System of linear equations
   • Gaussian Elimination
   • Reduced row echelon form
   • LU decomposition
► Vector spaces (*Hardest to understand personally*)
   • Span, basis, dimension
   • Inner product spaces
   • Column, row, null, left null spaces, rank theorem
   • Gram-Schmidt process
   • Least-squares problem
► Determinants
   • Laplace expansion, Leibniz formula
   • Properties of determinants
► Eigenvalues & Eigenvectors
   • Eigenvalue problem
   • Matrix diagonlisation
   • Symmetric & Hermitian matrix

=== Part 2: Differential Equations ===
► Introduction to ordinary differential equations (ODEs)
► First-order ODEs
   • Euler's method
   • Separable equations
   • Linear equations
   • Applications of first-order ODEs (Compound interest, terminal velocity, escape velocity, RC circuit)
► Second-order ODEs w/ constant coefficients
   • Euler's method
   • Principle of superposition & The Wronskian
   • Homogeneous ODEs
   • Difference equation
   • Inhomogeneous ODEs (Find particular solution)
   • Resonance (Combining homogeneous and particular solutions) (*Personally have trouble understanding*)
   • Applications of second-order ODEs (RLC circuit) (*Personally have trouble understanding*)
► Second-order ODEs w/ nonconstant coefficients
   • Power series ansatz
► System of linear differential equations
   • Find the general solution (Requires eigenvalues & eigenvectors from part 1)
   • Phase-space diagram
► Normal modes (Spring mass system)
reviews.comment_teaching:
He teaches at a pace that I can follow, writes on the whiteboard and you can cross-reference his notes simultaneously. Though at times I was very confused by some topics (*cough* vector spaces, resonance and RLC circuit *cough*). Seeing more examples in tutorial worksheets or asking him directly will slowly clear up your confusion.

Just before the midterm and final, he will do a content review and tell you exactly which topics will be tested in the exam (for our final he told us exactly which question examines which topic), so focus your revision on those topics only.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute OR Relative grading depends on which is more beneficial to the student
A range under absolute grading requires a total score >=90, so you need to be *VERY VERY*  close to full marks in both exams
For those less ambitious, the B range requires a total score >=80

► Tutorial worksheets 10%
(*TUTORIAL ATTENDANCE*)
You only need to *attempt* the worksheet and you usually get 2/2 despite not getting the correct answer or fully completing their requirements.

► Midterm 40%
Scope: Part 1 content only
6 questions in 1.5 hours
Statistics: Mean 49.74/60; Median 52/60

Practice with the worksheet questions / Coursera questions
Find past papers (as they're not provided officially) to become familiar with the exam design
He says he usually reuses and modifies Coursera or past paper questions for exam papers, so you know what to do

► Final 50%
Scope: Part 2 content only (non-cumulative, except you need to use eigenvalues & eigenvectors)
8 questions in 2 hours
Statistics: Mean 60.58; Median 63.5

Basically same as the midterm, but some questions require more time to complete, so work fast!
reviews.comment_workload:
Only tutorial attendance is mandatory

Optionally, you can spend your own time completing the tutorial worksheet, completing the Coursera questions, or watching the Coursera videos

reviews.comment_content: The content is suitable.

reviews.author: SQ Flyer
reviews.title: A+ Easy-going professor, manageable practices & simple exams
reviews.comment_content:
The course is divided into two parts, Matrix Algebra (Midterm) and Ordinary Differential Equation (Final).

A. Matrix Algebra
1. Complex Numbers

2. Matrices
(Definitions and Properties of matrices)

3. System of Linear Equations
(Gaussian Elimination, Reduced row echelon form, computing inverses, LU decomposition)

4. Vector Spaces
(Linear independence, span, basis, dimension, inner product spaces, null space, row space, column space, left null space, rank, gram-schmidt process, orthogonal projections, least-square problem)

5. Determinants
(Laplace expansion, Leibniz Formula, and properties)

6. Eigenvalues & Eigenvectors
(matrix diagonalization)

The midterm stress much on vector spaces and eigenvalues & eigenvectors with matrix diagonalization.

B. ODE
1. First Order ODE
(separable and linear equations, applications)

2. Second order ODE
(principle of superposition, Wronskian, homogeneous and inhomogeneous equations, resonance, applications with non-dimensionalization)

3. Series solutions of homogeneous linear second order equations (Ordinary points)

4. Systems of linear differential equations
(Normal Modes applications and phase space diagrams)


You can just understand the content covered in the lecture notes which can be downloaded from prof's homepage. Textbook is not necessary. The course is mainly designed for engineering students with few stress on rigorous mathematical proofs and deductions, so if you can deal with the computations, no big deal.

In this semester, most students are from CIVL and only some from MECH or other major. So, it turns out to be a Civil Engineering course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor simply follows the lecture notes and use the examples covered. You can watch his Youtube/ Coursera videos if you want to learn in a faster pace or review the lecture content. The professor would also provide some additional explanations for some harder concepts and computations. Overall speaking, Prof Chasnov did a good job in delivering the content and I would say he is an easy-going and responsible person.

The tutorial is simply reviewing the lecture content with extra demonstrations of different applications, then students will have time to work on the tutorial problems. You can just work the problems prior to the tutorials if you download the worksheets and submit to the TA directly, this definitely save your time. Yunfei can help answer student's questions in tutorials.

Solutions will be provided on the tutorial homepage. Just work on it seriously as the exams are based on the tutorial work.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment Mode:
10% Weekly tutorial worksheets
(zero mark for no submission, one mark for minimal efforts, two marks for sufficient efforts)

40% Midterm
(8 questions with 10 marks each, 90 mins)

50% Final
(Online Exam due to social movement and Wuhan virus, 4 questions with 10 marks each, 2 hrs)

I would say the exams are simply just steps memorization provided that the professor gave past papers for practices and useful tips for exams. The questions are just similar to those in past paper this semester. Just drill the past paper and done given that you paid sufficient efforts understanding the content. The professor seems to be very lenient this semester. So good!

Statistics:
Tutorial Worksheets Full mark
Midterm 77/80
Final 40/40
overall: 98.5%

Grade: A+, btw over 50 students receive A+ lol, the prof is crazily mad!

Two grading systems are provided, the absolute and relative one. Due to the very easy exams, scoring extremely high marks can guarantee you getting A-range without difficulty.

If you score almost full mark (say >97%), you will simply get an A+ under the absolute grading scheme.
reviews.comment_workload:
Overall speaking, it is not a very hard course, but I would say you should spend extra time on Vector Spaces, matrix diagonalization for the first part. And spend time solving the equations with different ansatz and the application problems in the second part. These are the harder topics in exams.

Weekly workload is just the tutorial worksheets, just need to pay some efforts and getting full marks is an easy task if you submit on time. After-lecture practices can be done using the worksheet given in the tutorials and the Coursera exercises which I personally suggest you to do so since some problems may appear identically in the exams. The Coursera problems can be obtained from the Notes,
i.e. Matrix Algebra / Differential Equations for Engineers

reviews.author: shirayuki653
reviews.comment_content:
Before midterm: Linear algebra(notations,matrices,systems of linear equations,vector spaces,determinants,eigenvalues and eigenvectors)

After midterm: Differential equations(separable ODEs, First-order ODEs, Second-order ODEs, Systems of 1st order differential equations, Nonlinear ODEs), Complex numbers will be used(just DSE level). Final is non-cumulative.

This course is all about computations and no proofs are required, so this is designed for non-math majors(e.g CIVL, MECH,OST) in order to grasp math skills for later courses. Therefore, you just need to master all the computations so that you can get a good grade.

The teaching of TA is better since she is familiar with the materials, she can provide effective ways to solve the problems. The only thing bad is that her English is hard to understand.

reviews.author: chpoonag
reviews.title: Master the worksheets, master the course.
reviews.comment_content:
The 1st part of the course was about linear algebra, including matrices, and some special techniques like Gram-Schmidt Process. In my opinion, you had better understand the principle thoroughly such that you do not need to remember the ways of computation, or so-called formulae, given that you have some basic knowledge of matrix computations (M2).

The 2nd part of the course was about differential equation. Only linear differential equations were taught in this course. This part may requires much memorization of techniques for computing, and there were different conditions corresponding to different computation "tricks", like finding the general solutions for linear inhomogeneous equations.

The midterm paper and final paper just contained the 1st and 2nd part RESPECTIVELY, ie no questions about the 1st part were in the final exam. Questions in exams were promised to be similar to the tutorial worksheets. In addition, n the final exam, there was an ODE application question (about terminal velocity). This application question was  chosen from the tutorial worksheet about the ODE application as guaranteed. Some may think that as calculators are not allowed n exam, we can just skip those questions requiring calculators in the worksheets. Yet, I observed that the professor would modify the question such that those requiring calculators initially contained no numerical calculations in the end, ie numbers were replaced by variables. For this question, I would say setting the equation is the most and the only difficult part.

Also, there was 2 questions not included n the tutorial worksheets: non-dimensionalizing an ODE and a spring-mass system equation (guaranteed to be with 2-4 identical blocks and 0-2 walls at the left and right ends and identical springs between blocks and between a block and a wall).
reviews.comment_teaching:
You can purchase the book printed by the Math department at $40 although there was something printed wrongly. Prof CHASNOV pointed out in class as he taught us with reference to this notes. This book can help you catch up the learning progress if you do not understand something in class, despite having many words.

Some may find his speaking is too slow, but for me, it is suitable, as you often need some time to digest the content.

He was patient enough to explain what was taught in class if you asked him after class. However, sometimes he may not be able to understand how you think of or view one thing, even when your way of understanding was correct yet different from the professor's.
reviews.comment_grading:
*Tutorial Worksheets : 10%
Midterm : 40%
Final : 50%

*Tutorial class can be skipped given that you have submitted before the class by means of, for instance, sending email. The worksheets were more or less identical to the previous year's ones.
2 marks each. Basically, if you can accomplish "with effort", you can get full mark already.

Grading scheme can be either relative or absolute. Whichever more favourable to you is applied. You may request for an F if you get D in the end.

Absolute grading scheme :
97-100  A+
93-96  A
90-92  A-
87-89  B+
83-86  B
80-82  B-
77-79  C+
73-76  C
70-72  C-
65-69  D
<65  F

Relative grading:
score > mean+1sd: A range
score > mean: B range
score > mean - 1sd: C range
score > mean - 2sd: D
score < mean - 2sd: F

**Questions were similar to tutorial worksheets so be cautious not to make any careless mistake at the beginning of each question.

Item, Score, Full mark, Mean:
Worksheets, 26, 26, 22.99(my section)
Midterm, 69, 80, 45.77
Final, 76, 80, 39.02
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: Only 1 worksheet per week, and you can just refer to last year's worksheets solutions if you would like to and if you have.

reviews.author: Anisha
reviews.comment_content: Divided into 2 parts- linear algebra and differential equations. The midterm this semester was unusually difficult and as usual, the final was pretty difficult, too. The content is pretty straightforward and you only gotta practice the worksheets to get a hang of what's to come in the exams.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Chasnov is a good teacher who makes sure to include all the steps in his calculations in class and tries to explain in detail. He even gives a recap of everything done in the lecture at the end, which I thought was very useful. Also, very friendly and approachable.
The TA was also very helpful in explaining problems and giving useful feedback on practice papers before the exams. He was very prompt in replying to emails.
reviews.comment_grading:
As the exams were pretty difficult this semester, I think the grading was more lenient than before.
Midterm: 68/80, mean: 50/80
Finals: 58/80, mean: I guess much lower than that?
submitted all worksheets
Final grade: 79% and A-
reviews.comment_workload: The worksheets are graded based on how much effort you put in, not accuracy. You don't even have to show up at tutorials, just email the TA your solutions and you'll get full marks. Doing those worksheets and practice papers diligently will earn you a good grade for sure.

reviews.author: Lily321
reviews.comment_content:
This course teach basics of linear algebra and differential equation.
The content include:
-Linear system and matrix algebra
-Vector spaces and inner product spaces
-Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
-First order and homogeneous second order ODEs
-System of first order linear ODEs

This course didn't go deep with each topics, only teach the basic concepts and some simple problems.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The Professor basically just read the PPT and I cannot really learn anything from his lecture. The manner he teach is not quit suitable for people without solid Math background.
He did some examples at the end of lectures in a very fast way that I cannot learn anything at all.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is good overall.
15% webwork and matlab quiz
35% Midterm
50% Final

The Midterm and final is similar with the webwork and tutorial problems, not especially difficult. The MatLab quiz is, however, very confusing. Since the professor give only some examples and there are no practice problems and DO NOT have ANY FORMAL NOTES (with only a command manual), it is very hard to revise.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not very high compare with MATH2011. The webwork is launch each 1-2 week, the first few is easy.
The content is not much, so the revision does't take very long, but indeed take sometime to practice some question from tutorial. If you do all the webwork yourself, the practice will not take up lots of time.

reviews.comment_content:
-Matrix (math2111)
-differetual equation(math2351)
-octave
reviews.comment_teaching: He really tried his best to teach, but he spoke too fast with many difficult math symbol. Also he used a lot of time to teach octave so always left less time on note. About hos note, very few example and most of them have NO STEP.
reviews.comment_grading: Not very bad, the midterm is very easy, just included some simple question, if you do webwork yourself, there is no way that you cant do the long question. Final is harder, and the MC question consist some ocatve knowledge, they were very difficult and some.of them were not mentioned during the lesson

reviews.author: 學渣
reviews.comment_content: Pre-Registered for Civil Engineering students, and the course included the materials in MATH 2111(Matrix) and MATH 2351(Differential Equation), in addition, Octave is also included. (Octave can help you to calculate matrix, plot diagram and solve equations)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Poor PPTs and presentation, even though you attended the lesson, you probably can't understand what the instructor taught.
The only knowledge you can get from the lesson would be the operation of Octave and able to copy his examples written on the whiteboard (that is not included in the PPT).

For tutorials, it depends on which class do you attend, some of them are quite good. My TA is good and trying to explain most of the questions in the tutorial notes. Even though he can't finish all the question, he will upload the steps and answer for us.
reviews.comment_grading:
There will be 3 quiz(@1%) to test your knowledge on the operation of Octave (During the tutorial time). However, the TA will help you in the quiz (So I think the quiz is just for taking attendance)

The grading is normal for MATH courses, if you can get mean score in average you can probably get B-.
reviews.comment_workload:
WebWork every 2 weeks, with maximum 10 questions, sometimes there are only 4-5 questions. 3 Quiz in total (Just take 5-10 mins in Math Support Centre)

Workload seems not to be that heavy, but as mentioned, the course included MATH 2111 and MATH 2351. The teaching pace is actually fast and the instructor can't explain the content clearly in-class, so you probably have to spent a lot of time at home to study the content (You can study the materials from 2111 and 2351 separately)

reviews.author: HelloDude
reviews.comment_content:
This course is about matrices and ordinary differential equations (ODEs).

Matrices contains basic matrix calculations, vector spaces, subspace, eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

ODEs just contains the fundamental parts but they are hard enough for students.

The notes are horrible, difficult proofs of theory fill the pages of the notes which is useless for engineering students . I think the proofs should not be taught in intro course, it should appear in math major courses.

And Octave commands are tested in three quizzes (1% each) but I strongly disagree it is asked in exams.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lee Wing Lung is obvious the worst teacher ever. He doesn't know teaching and spends a lot of time to play Octave (mathematical software) with his computer. I usually fell asleep when he did that. I learned most of the content  from tutorials by Xu Wei, a very nice tutor who can speak cantonese.
reviews.comment_grading: To be fair, I believe the grading is quite acceptable. Although my midterm grade was slightly higher than mean and my final exam grade met the mean, I still had B. Pretty great!
reviews.comment_workload: 12 webwork homework, easy questions and you can find the answers online.

reviews.author: wwongad
reviews.title: For future students that need to take this course, be prepared
reviews.comment_content:
This course are divided into 2 major parts:
1. Applied Linear Algebra (MATH2111)
2. Ordinary Differential Equation (MATH2350)

Intended Learning Objectives :
1 Manipulate systematically a system of linear equations.
2 Manipulate the basic algebra and computation techniques of matrices and determinants, and invoke MATLAB (or substitutes) to help the computations.
3 Describe the basic terminologies appeared in vector spaces and inner product spaces.
4 Formulate the concept and properties of eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a matrix, and operate the diagonalization process and recognize the applications.
5 Describe the solutions of simple first order ODEs analytically, and graphically with the help of MATLAB (or substitutes).
6 Comprehend the solution behaviors of second order linear ODEs with constant coefficients, and recognize their roles in free and forced oscillations.
7 Describe the solutions of a homogeneous system of first order ODEs with constant coefficients analytically, and numerically with the help of MATLAB (or substitutes).

But I don't think that you're going to achieve any of these :)
reviews.comment_teaching:
If you got enrolled with him in any math course ever, send your prayer and hope you won't fuck up in that course.
Attending his class=nothing. You can use his lecture time to do other thing. His way of teaching is shit. You won't understand everything he said. I never see any math teachers or professors teach math only by reading all the letters in the notes. His notes contain a lot of words (in b/w) so you will have hard time understanding what he wrote on that paper.

Moreover, we need to learn about GNU Octave (Matlab rip-off because it's free) and he will do demonstration in several class that are somehow going to be tested in exam. But his demos were unclear and we don't have any time to ask him because he always moved on to other slides
reviews.comment_grading:
12% WebWork
3% GNU Octave Quiz
35% Midterm
Most of students will tell you this exam was pretty easy. It is somewhat true because mean/sd are 80/12.5 out of 100

50% Final
Harder than midterm exam. Mean/sd are 65.1/15.6

I think his marking scheme for both exams are pretty fair. He won't deduct a lot of points if you got some answer correct (even though your final answer is incorrect)
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly webwork and tutorial exercises that probably will help you to do the exam a bit. And luckily there are no attendance to this course :)

reviews.author: Pasindu
reviews.title: Avoid this professor like the plague.
reviews.comment_content: The course is divided into 2 parts; linear algebra and differential equation. The Linear Algebra part is quite manageable. The Differential equation part is tougher.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Without a doubt one of the worst, if not, the worst professor in HKUST. He does not know how to teach at all. He teaches a Math course by reading off the presentation The presentation and lecture notes are mostly senseless. It's just full of symbols and a few basic examples.
He is unwilling to answer questions during lectures, and most of the time students are lost and have no clue of what is happening.
However you can't miss lectures because he demonstrates how to do some MATLAB commands. This demonstration is worse than his teaching. He just randomly types some commands in, and then shows the result and moves on.
I had to learn everything through the textbook, and had minimal use of lecture notes.
HKUST GET IT TOGETHER, WE ARE NOT PAYING YOU GOOD MONEY TO LEARN FROM TEXTBOOKS. REMOVE PROFESSORS LIKE THIS FROM YOUR STAFF.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm is easy, if you managed to learn through textbooks and other sources. Final is harder. Consists of questions which were not properly covered in lecture sessions.
Midterm mean - 80
Final Mean - 65
reviews.comment_workload:
Very high for a math course. Course is extremely disorganized. They try to cram too much of content into one course.
You will have Webwork every few days.
Within the last 2 weeks of semester he will go through almost 120 pages of lecture notes.
You can understand how bad his teaching is when he teaches that much in such little time.

reviews.author: Itsme
reviews.title: Easy course for people without any related background
reviews.comment_content:
Divided into 2 parts
Part 1: Matrix Algebra
1. Matices
2. System of Linear Equations
3. Vector Spaces
4. Eigenvalues and Eigenvector
--------------------------------------
Part 2: Differential Equations

reviews.comment_grading:
Great

- Coursera assessed quiz: 10%
- Midterm: 20%

Differential Equation: 60%
- Textbook practice quiz:10%
-  Coursera assessed quiz: 10%
- Final: 30%

My score:
Midterm: 36/50 (Mean:36/50)
Final : 48/60 (Mean: 39.3/50)

The grading is good. If you submit all the homework on Coursera and the textbook quizzes, you will be able to earn 50 marks from the course. And it is easy for people without a related background in the secondary school like me as there will be a past paper provided. It is very similar to the examination. And it was okay to revise a few days ago.
Practice makes perfect!!!!

fair.

reviews.author: cheese
reviews.title: A simplified Math course
reviews.comment_content:
The course is divided into two parts.
The first part is mainly composed of basic DSE complex number, M2 matrix knowledge, 4x4 determinant, eigenvalue, eigenvector and LU decomposition, which will be tested only in the midterm.
The second part is mainly composed of differential equations including first and second-ode differential equations, which will be tested in the final exam. They are not so difficult if you remember some basic formulas.
reviews.comment_teaching: Chasnov has an interesting accent but he explains well on the topics. Though I started skipping lessons after midterm, I did just fine on the final exam. He also gave us tips on midterm and final exam. A practice was given before the midterm and the midterm had roughly the same style as the practice. Eventually I got full mark on midterm. I love Xu Wei as my tutor as he teaches great and speaks Cantonese. (and handsome as well)
reviews.comment_grading:
30%Midterm
50%Final
20%Assignment
Got full mark in Midterm and assignment because midterm is super easy and the mean is around 44 out of 50.
Final is a bit difficult because I need to apply the knowledge of eigenvalue/eigenvector on the second ode differential equations.
I got 80% for final which gives me 90% overall, Grade is A-.
90above for A range so one must get high mark in midterm.
reviews.comment_workload: As said by students taking this course in the previous semesters,  the course was a disaster and it included lots of materials and required a large number of memorizations. But now, the professor listened to the students' opinions and decided to change. The workload is extremely small. I just needed to attend the tutorial to finish some questions and took the assignment mark every week. The tutor will talk about them and the questions are not very difficult.

reviews.author: Jackma
reviews.comment_content:
Part1:Linear Algebra
Week 1:
Course introduction; complex numbers
Week 2:
Matrices, transposes, inverses, rotations, permutations, projections
Week 3:
Gaussian elimination, reduced row echelon form, inverses, LU decomposition
Week 4:
Vector and inner-product spaces,
Week 5:
Four fundamental vector spaces of a matrix, Gram-Schmidt, orthogonal projections
Week 6:
Least squares, determinants
Week 7:
Eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization
Part2:Differential equations
Week 8
Introduction to odes, Euler method, separable equations, linear equations
Week 9
Applications, Euler method 2D, superposition, Wronskian
Week 10
Homogeneous odes, difference equations, inhomogeneous odes
Week 11
Inhomogeneous odes, resonance, applications, damped resonance
Week 12
Series solutions, systems of first-order linear odes
Week 13
Normal modes, Final exam review
Midterm前教Part1, Midterm後教Part2
reviews.comment_teaching:

Jeffrey 會喺考試前講每一題會出咩，跟住嚟溫就ok，做齊worksheet同埋清concept，考試題目唔係好難。
Tutorial: 每個星期都有tutorial，基本上就係聽 tutor講嘢同埋做worksheet，tutor講嘢好細聲，唔係好聽到佢講嘢，worksheet唔係好難。
